Study: Suicide risk double among male U.S. veterans





The risk of suicide among male U.S. veterans is double that of the general
population, according to a study published Monday.





FULL STORY
















Afghanistan: U.S. mistakenly kills police officers





U.S. forces mistakenly killed seven Afghan police and wounded four in an
apparent friendly fire incident early Tuesday in eastern Afghanistan, Afghan
officials said.

Bangladesh death toll rises to 82





Torrential rains hammered southeastern Bangladesh early Tuesday, a day after
the unusually powerful monsoon triggered landslides, flash floods and
lightning killing at least 82 people, rescue officials and witnesses said.

Officer charged in taped beating apparently kills himself 





A former New Orleans police officer charged in the videotaped beating of a man
after Hurricane Katrina apparently shot himself to death about a month before
his trial, authorities said Monday.





FULL STORY
















Infant twins among 6 bodies in Wisconsin home





A domestic dispute erupted into a mass killing in southern Wisconsin, leaving
six people, including two infant boys, shot to death, and a 2-year-old girl
with a gunshot to her chest.





FULL STORY
      WATCH VIDEO
















Last minute appeal in teen sex case sparks outrage 





Jubilation turned to anger Monday after Georgia's top prosecutor vowed he
would fight a judge's order that would have set free Genarlow Wilson, a
Georgia man serving a 10-year prison sentence for a consensual sexual
encounter he had as a teenager.





FULL STORY
      WATCH VIDEO
















Families feel 'ostracized' in Virginia Tech probe





The families of some of the 32 people killed on Virginia Tech's campus
demanded representation Monday on a gubernatorial panel studying the killings,
saying they feel "ostracized."

RPG fired at home of Palestinian prime minister





The house of Palestinian Prime Minister Ismail Haniya came under
rocket-propelled grenade fire Tuesday morning, the Hamas media office
reported. There were no injuries.





FULL STORY
















Federal court rules against  enemy combatant policy 





A divided panel from a conservative federal appeals court delivered a harsh
rebuke to the Bush administration's anti-terrorism strategy Monday, ruling
that U.S. residents cannot be locked up indefinitely as "enemy combatants"
without being charged.





FULL STORY
















Colombia ordered to pay millions in massacre case





In a ruling hailed as a landmark by human rights advocates, the Colombian
government has been ordered to pay damages over a 1989 massacre of state
investigators by army-backed militias.





FULL STORY
















Daughter slain in 'honor killing'





A Kurdish man was convicted in a London court on Monday of murdering his
20-year-old daughter in a so-called "honor killing" after she left her husband
and fell in love with another man.

BUSINESS
 CNNmoney.com 








CEOs: Riding off into the (well-funded) sunset





The world of corporate pensions may be shrinking, but it's still fairly robust
at S&P 500 companies. And that's true for no one more so than the current crop
of the companies' already highly paid CEOs, who have accrued retirement
benefits worth over $2 billion today, according to a report released Monday.





FULL STORY
















Bancrofts set new proposals - report





The Bancroft family, controlling shareholders of Dow Jones & Co. Inc., are set
to submit a new set of proposals to News Corp. on how to protect the Wall
Street Journal's editorial independence, the Journal reported on Monday.

SPORTS
 SI.com 








Ian Thomsen: Spurs' Big Three putting its stamp on Finals





SAN ANTONIO -- The preparation for the Spurs' 2-0 lead in the NBA Finals began
four years ago, when Zydrunas Ilgauskas was getting his legs back after
multiple foot surgeries, Larry Hughes was missing the playoffs with Washington
and LeBron James was a senior in high school. While those players seemed ages
away from ever reaching the Finals, the Spurs were winning what may soon be
recast as the first of three championships in a five-year span. Those
experiences are making all of the difference now.





FULL STORY
















John Donovan: MLB Power Rankings





If the season ended this week -- and, of course, the season doesn't end for
another 600 or 700 weeks, by my calculations -- I would be perfectly happy
with the top eight teams in the Power Rankings making the playoffs. They're
fine franchises, every one of them, many with deep pitching, some with pretty
good hitting and each with a chance to go all the way to the World Series.
Whenever that is.

'Juvenile' diabetes at 49: 'You deal with it' 





A year before turning 50, Michele Thomas learned she had type 1 diabetes, a
condition that used to be associated mainly with children.

Thousands claiming vaccine-autism link get day in court





The parents of 12-year-old Michelle Cedillo asked a federal court Monday to
find that their child's autism was caused by common childhood vaccines, a
precedent-setting case that could pave the way for thousands of autistic
children to receive compensation from a government fund set up to help people
injured by the shots.

Apple Inc. launched a version of its Safari Web browser for Windows-based PCs
on Monday, pitting it against Microsoft Corp.'s dominant Internet Explorer and
Mozilla's Firefox.
